div.head: For casting in silver
div.ab:
You need to arrange your animals as said and compose the same sand two parts d out of 4 parts of plaster, of two parts reheated brick, & one part reheated feather alum, and mix it well. Then, having been prepared thus, and you wishing to mold it, take the three parts of an earthenware bowl, from which the peasants eat their soup, of the aforesaid sand, & add to it pure feather alum, reheated & pulverized in the mortar, as much as you can take with 4 fingers and the thumb, or a small double handful. Then, mix mix well & wet with a little sal ammoniac & the rest of the common water, + & stir it with your spatula so that it all becomes like a thick sauce or thin mustard, & having rubbed the animal with eau-de-vie with the paintbrush, cast, & blow, and beat the table to shake the mold, & do as with others.
Do not forget to put in it crocum, for it prevents the molds from cracking & is appropriate for all metals.
Alloyed silver is better for casting than the fine one, provided that it is sweet.
One needs the feather alum to be well pulverized and well mixed.
Sal ammoniac is a friend of gold & of silver.

ab.add: which needs to be placed before the sand in the bowl, which is put in the water, & not the water in the sand

div.ab: Latten is the enemy of gold & the friend of silver.
